ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thought about mathematicians, among them the fact that their job is not to prove theorems but to communicate ideas.

X.T: La symétrie ici et là

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It is a pity that, given the speaker, the level of the presentation is so low and the last part, which gets philosophical, could have been more interesting if it would have been better presented.

X.T: The physics of the Web

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A further Web analysis: the Web appears to be a network ruled by a power-law distribution.

X.T: The Church-Turing Thesis: Story and Recent Progress

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The premises of Church-Turing thesis, the thesis itself and the current work on it (abstract state machines).

X.T: Fast Route Planning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a quick presentation of the algorithm, PeterSanders presents some current uses and some possible future improvements to more complex problems.

X.T: Learning Low Dimensional Manifolds

ARTICLE.COMMENT: YoavFreund presents the random projection trees algorithm used to extract the few intrinsic dimensions in a highly-constrained high-dimensional system.

X.T: Demain : quel temps ? Un mathématicien en visite chez Chronos

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The presentation of some subjects more or less linked to time, but their presentation is very high level, so you have to know about them beforehand and, and the connection between the subjects is unclear.

X.T: 3 is everywhere - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The percentage of numbers containing 3 tends toward 100% when considering more and more numbers.

X.T: Des particules, des étoiles et des probabilités

ARTICLE.COMMENT: From the study of system solar stability to a proof of Landau damping.

X.T: One to One Million - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The usual story about Gauss's integer sum and adding all the digits of numbers from 1 to 1000000.

X.T: New Wikipedia sized proof explained with a puzzle

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Erdős discrepancy problem has been proved for C=2 using a computer.

X.T: The Most Difficult Program to Compute? - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Ackermann's function.

X.T: The Man Who Tried to Redeem the World with Logic
X.ST: Walter Pitts rose from the streets to MIT, but couldn’t escape himself.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The life of Walter Pitts who worked with Warren McCulloch, Jerome Lettvin, and Patrick Wall, to understand how the brain works.

X.T: In Mathematics, Mistakes Aren’t What They Used To Be
X.ST: Computers can’t invent, but they’re changing the field anyway.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using computers for mathematical demonstrations, in particular as proof assistants.

X.T: [François Sauvageot] One-maths show ! Et si on parlait des maths ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Miscellaneous mathematical trivia.

X.T: Answer to a 150-Year-Old Math Conundrum Brings More Mystery

ARTICLE.COMMENT: PeterKeevash proved a major advance in block design.

X.T: Wobbly Circles - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very simple triangle problem, but the proof that the center of mass is always at the same height is missing…

X.T: Heptadecagon and Fermat Primes (the math bit) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Constructible angles and Fermat numbers.

X.T: Fifth Root Trick - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A trick to calculate fifth root in one's head.

X.T: How many chess games are possible?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Several persons tried to evaluate the number of possible chess games.

X.T: Martin Gardner 101

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about Martin Gardner.

X.T: Infinity Paradoxes - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Four paradoxes with infinity: Hilbert's hotel, Gabriel's trumpet, the puzzle of the dartboard, double your money.

X.T: Order from Chaos - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Arranging 0, 1… 9 so there is no four digits in ascending or descending order.

X.T: Shapes and Hook Numbers - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Standard Young tables and Hook lengths.

X.T: Shapes and Hook Numbers (extra footage)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: The 'Everything' Formula - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Tupper's self-referential formula.

X.T: Vulgarizators 2.0 - MICMATHS - L'élégance en mathématiques

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some well-known problems having a simple elegant solution: the mutilated chessboard, the sum of integers…

X.T: Freaky Dot Patterns - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Moiré Patterns.

X.T: The Mathematics of Crime and Terrorism - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Hawkes Process.

X.T: Loïc Le Marrec - Comment représenter les contraintes mécaniques ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all, but there is little here, just the fact that maths are used to modelise physics.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information on Ramanujan's work on partitions.

X.T: Ramanujan and Partitions (extra footage)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: Perplexing Paperclips - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to predict how to paperclips and two rubber bands will behave when placed on a strip of paper that is unfolded.

X.T: Subtracting Paperclips - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous video.

X.T: Consecutive Coin Flips - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Average waiting time to get heads-heads vs average waiting time to get heads-tails.

X.T: Bernard Le Stum - Perfectoïdes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to perfectoid fields.

X.T: Riemann's paradox: pi = infinity minus infinity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Riemann rearrangement theorem.

X.T: Top 5 des problèmes de maths simples mais non résolus - Micmaths

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Collatz conjecture, the Ramsey numbers, the Lychrel numbers, the chromatic number of the plane, and the multiplicative persistence.

X.T: Stars and Bars (and bagels) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to compute the number of ways to choose 12 bagels when 4 flavours are available.

X.T: The Flaw in Reductio Ad Absurdum

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subject of provability is interesting, but the author does not master it and this video is just gibberish.

X.T: Ramanujan's infinite root and its crazy cousins

ARTICLE.COMMENT: About infinite expressions and the meaning of these.

X.T: The Josephus Problem - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says all.

X.T: How Many Humans Have the Same Number of Body Hairs? | Infinite Series | PBS Digital Studios

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Pigeonhole Principle.

X.T: The Shortest Ever Papers - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some very short scientific papers: a counter-example of Euler conjecture, Nash's seminal paper on game theory…

X.T: Can You Solve the Poison Wine Challenge? | Infinite Series | PBS Digital

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Very basic stuff, this is only about binary representations. It is a pity she gives the solution of the puzzle at the very beginning.

X.T: Can We Hear Shapes? | Infinite Series | PBS Digital Studios

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Can two different 2D shapes be isospectral?

X.T: Singularities Explained | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some examples of mathematical singularities in the real world.

X.T: The Brachistochrone

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Creating a real-world cycloid to demonstrate it is brachistochronous and tautochronous.

X.T: The Map of Mathematics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Trying to draw a 2D map of the different domains of mathematics.

X.T: Infinite Chess | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction, first, on Zermelo's theorem, then on infinite chess.

X.T: 5 Unusual Proofs | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of some tools used in demonstrations by applying them in simple proofs.

X.T: Pascal's Triangle - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some properties of Pascal triangle.

X.T: Funny Fractions and Ford Circles - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to Farey Sequences and the (unexplained) fact that they appear in Ford circles.

X.T: Mickaël Launay : Le mystère de la farfalle - Tournée de Pi 2017

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some mathematical humor about pasta.

X.T: Building an Infinite Bridge | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to stack bricks to get the longest overhang.

X.T: Apéry's constant (calculated with Twitter) - Numberphile

X.T: Basile PIllet - Cohomologie des figures impossibles

X.T: The Devil's Staircase | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Cantor set and Cantor function.

X.T: Les chiffres... arabes ? - MLTP#17

X.T: The Impossible Mathematics of the Real World
X.ST: Near-miss math provides exact representations of almost-right answers.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some anecdotes of mathematical near-misses, but there is little explanation on how these can be exploited.

X.T: When do clock hands overlap? - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says alls.

X.T: Stochastic Supertasks | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A randomized extension of Ross-Littlewood Paradox.

X.T: Les fractions continues

X.T: Juggling by Numbers - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Theorizing juggling.

X.T: How to Generate Pseudorandom Numbers | Infinite Series

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two pseudorandom number algorithms (the middle-square algorithm and the linear congruential generator) and inverse transform sampling.

X.T: Crisis in the Foundation of Mathematics | Infinite Series

X.T: Pancake Numbers - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Pancake sorting.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Different types of auction system and some comments about them.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some well-known mathematical memes.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic introduction to quotient sets.

X.T: Number Sticks - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple clever calculation trick.

X.T: Arithmetic mean vs Geometric mean | inequality among means | visual proof

X.T: [Hervé Lehning] Les mathématiques pour comprendre le monde

ARTICLE.COMMENT: HervéLehning is marketing his book with basic well-known mathematics-anecdotes.

X.T: Antipodal Points - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An elegant (but not rigorous) proof of the fact that, if a sphere is split in two parts of the same area, it is possible to find a pair of antipodal points, one in each part.

X.T: Universal Method to Sort Complex Information Found
X.ST: The nearest neighbor problem asks where a new point fits into an existing data set. A few researchers set out to prove that there was no universal way to solve it. Instead, they found such a way.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some progress has been done on the nearest neighbor problem, but the article gives little explanation on these recent papers.

X.T: A Proof About Where Symmetries Can’t Exist
X.ST: In a major mathematical achievement, a small team of researchers has proven Zimmer’s conjecture.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A proof of Zimmer's conjecture has been done, but this article cannot really describe such abstract mathematics.

X.T: Primes on the Moon (Lunar Arithmetic) - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of "lunar arithmetic" (previously known as "dismal arithmetic") and some properties of this one.

X.T: 𝕋urning a 𝔽unction into a ℝecursive 𝔽ormula?!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Unclear, very slow and poor humor.

X.T: The Trapped Knight - Numberphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An algorithm for moving a knight surprisingly gives a very long but finite path.

X.T: How a Strange Grid Reveals Hidden Connections Between Simple Numbers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the sum-product phenomenon.

X.T: Dessiner un éléphant avec un seul paramètre
X.ST: Reproduire n’importe quel jeu de données en nombre fini, par exemple des points qui esquissent la silhouette d’un animal : c’est l’exploit que permet une fonction paramétrisée par un unique nombre réel.

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
A single function with a single paramater that can be used to fit any number of points to any given precision (the original paper is herehttp://colala.berkeley.edu/papers/piantadosi2018one.pdf
frPDF).

X.T: A Path Less Taken to the Peak of the Math World
X.ST: June Huh thought he had no talent for math until a chance meeting with a legendary mind. A decade later, his unorthodox approach to mathematical thinking has led to major breakthroughs.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The story of June Huh who proved Read’s conjecture and Heron-Rota-Welsh conjecture conjecture.

X.T: Indian Maths Genius Who Debunked Euler’s Theory, Made it to NYT Front Page Dies at 103
X.ST: Sharadchandra Shankar Shrikhande, who along with his mentor and an American colleague disproved in 1959 what had been an unsolved 177-year old mathematical conjecture, passes away at 103.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A biography of SharadchandraShankarShrikhande and the disproof of Euler's conjecture.

X.T: Karen Uhlenbeck, Uniter of Geometry and Analysis, Wins Abel Prize
X.ST: A founder of modern geometric analysis who produced “some of the most dramatic advances in mathematics in the last 40 years,” Uhlenbeck is the first woman to be awarded this top honor.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A biography of KarenUhlenbeck.

X.T: The Oracle of Arithmetic
X.ST: At 28, Peter Scholze is uncovering deep connections between number theory and geometry.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Peter Scholze's work, in particular the perfectoid spaces.

X.T: Mathematician-M.D. introduces a new methodology suggesting a solution to one of the greatest open problems in the history of mathematics
X.ST: A completely new approach suggests the validity of the 110-year-old Lindelöf hypothesis, opening up the possibilities of new discoveries in quantum computing, number theory and cybersecurity

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information about Athanassios Fokas after his findings on the Lindelöf Hypothesis (the rate of growth of the Riemann zeta function on the critical line).
